metadata.subject: Q&A on the USA, with a watchful eye on the risk of giant man-eating plants; Spain

relationships.description: Chief Investment Officer of J.P. Morgan Private Bank
Co-authors of economic paper on fiscal policy
Spain may require financial support from European institutions

analysis.purpose: Provide economic analysis and investment commentary on US and European economic conditions
analysis.significance: Comprehensive economic analysis from J.P. Morgan's CIO discussing US recovery, fiscal policy, and specific concerns about Spain's economic situation

notable_quotes: The point: some amazing events which look benign have unforeseen consequences.
The only country I can find that's in worse shape than Spain is: Greece
Will a pact of going for growth pay the freight of higher Federal debt in the long run? Hard to say; there are not a lot of examples to draw from.
red_flags: Spain's potential need for 1.5 trillion Euros in borrowing during recession
13 historical defaults by Spain since 1500 AD
Underfunded state pension liabilities that may be underestimated

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this economic analysis document

illegal_activity.description: Document is an economic analysis report with no illegal activity discussed

details: Reference to New York Times article by Austan Goolsbee from 2007

public_knowledge.context: Economic analysis and market commentary from major financial institution would be of interest to financial media and investors

analysis.summary: This J.P. Morgan economic analysis from April 2012 provides a Q&A format examination of US economic recovery trends, fiscal policy challenges, and specific concerns about Spain's economic stability, while using literary references to warn about unforeseen consequences of current economic policies.
